awd_titl_txt: Ambitious Math and Science Teaching Fellows
awd_abstract_narration:
This Noyce Teaching Fellows project will provide training for 16 teaching fellows to complete a Master's degree program for licensure in secondary mathematics or science teaching.  The project will also provide professional development and support for the participants during their first four years of teaching in high needs schools.  The key elements of the project are (a) research-based teacher preparation courses and clinical experiences, (b) professional development to support induction, and (c) support for teacher retention.  The ambitious teaching philosophy, which promotes instructional practices and routines that support every student, across racial, ethnic, gender, and linguistic boundaries as they learn essential ideas within a discipline, will be central to the curriculum.  This project will be carried out by Oregon State University in partnership with the Mid-Valley Math and Science Network, six Mid-Valley School Districts, and the Teachers Development Group, a non-profit organization that designs professional development plans that focus on improving students' mathematical understanding and achievement.

The project's goal is to provide fellows with a Master's degree program and follow-up professional opportunities that use an evidence-based teaching model, which focuses on the development of strategies that will support students from diverse backgrounds with an emphasis on solving real-world problems.  The fellows will be introduced to the foundations of this ambitious teaching model (high leverage teaching practices, equitable instruction, and discipline-specific practices) during the Master's program and continue to refer back to these foundations once they have been placed in the classroom.  The investigators hypothesize that the ambitious teaching model will be especially effective in STEM classrooms in high-needs schools.  Project evaluation will address this premise through assessment of the fellows' continuing progress (Mathematical Quality of Instruction) and formative teaching observation (EQUIP) during the induction phase.  The results and resources developed through this work will be disseminated through, the Mid-Valley Math Science Teaching Network, an established online network of Oregon teachers and administrators, and at meetings of the Teachers of Teachers of Mathematics.

por.por_cntn:
The Ambitious Math and Science (AM&S) Teaching Fellows project provided 16 students science with support to pursue teacher licensure through Oregon State University?s Masters degree program in mathematics and science education.    AM&S Teaching Fellows were provided with a $16,000 forgivable fellowship loan during the Masters degree licensure program as well as a full academic year of tuition remission through the Oregon State University Graduate School. 

 

The specific project objectives were as follows: 1) recruit students completing their undergraduate degrees and practicing professionals in the STEM disciplines into secondary education, 2) provide a high quality graduate program in Math and Science Education that builds upon STEM students? and professionals? undergraduate degrees in Science, Math, or Engineering, 3) increase the number of graduates with a MS in Science and Mathematics Education who are prepared and licensed to ambitiously teach Secondary Science or Mathematics aligned with state and national standards, and 4) provide ongoing professional development and membership in the existing Math and Science Teacher Network supporting continued learning of ambitious teaching. Ambitious teaching refers to instructional practices and routines that support every student, across racial, ethnic, gender, and linguistic boundaries, learning key ideas within a discipline with the aim of solving authentic problems.

 

Following successful completion of the Masters degree licensure program, each Teaching Fellow was expected to serve four years in a high needs local educational agency (LEA) defined by at least one of the following: high percentage of individuals from families with incomes below the poverty level, high percentage of secondary teachers not teaching in the content area in which they were trained, or high teacher turnover.  For each year served as a mathematics or science teacher in a high needs LEA, a Teaching Fellow received forgiveness of 25% of the fellowship loan as well as a $10,000 salary supplement.

 

Oregon State University?s Teacher Licensure Program for the preparation of science and mathematics teachers for grades 5-12 is a challenging program, emphasizing the development of a teacher?s ability to transform what he or she knows into teaching strategies that make that knowledge accessible to learners. Specific attention is paid to the knowledge, skills, and dispositions necessary to be a successful teacher of science and mathematics. Students must complete one part-time and one full-time student teaching practicum at the middle and high school levels.  Students successfully completing the program receive two authorizations (one at each level) and endorsements in at least one of the following areas: Advanced Mathematics, Basic Mathematics, Integrated Science, Biology, Chemistry, Physics.

 

The AM&S Teaching Fellows project provided mentorship and continuing professional development for these teachers to undertake ambitious teaching over their first four years of mathematics or science teaching service in high needs schools.  Teaching Fellows also received mentoring and professional development in preparation to take on leadership roles (curriculum development, mentoring, assisting in planning and implementing professional development, or participating in teacher education program).   

 

There were two full cohorts of Teaching Fellows.  During 2016-17, the first cohort of 6 science Teaching Fellows and 2 mathematics Teaching Fellows successfully completed the Masters degree program and were licensed to teach. All 8 of these Teaching Fellows went on to complete four years of teaching in high need school settings in 2017-21. During 2017-18, a second cohort of 3 science Teaching Fellows and 5 mathematics Teaching Fellows successfully completed the Masters degree program leading to teaching licensure.  All 8 of these Teaching Fellows will have completed their four years of teaching in high need school settings in 2018-22.

 

The AM&S project partnered with the Oregon Department of Education to organize and host three summer Ambitious Math and Science Teaching Conferences at Oregon State University in 2017, 2018, and 2019.  These conferences brought nationally recognized experts to work with math and science teachers from across the state of Oregon and also served as opportunities for continued professional development of the AM&S Teaching Fellows. The project also provided support for Teaching Fellows to attend other regional and national professional development events, such as Teachers Development Group?s annual Leadership Seminar, and regional or national Noyce conferences.  During the COVID19 pandemic, much of the project staff?s interaction with Teaching Fellows had to be handled through Zoom, and site visits to Teaching Fellows became impossible.  In the summer of 2021, the project was able to host a ?Data Summer Camp? retreat for both cohorts of Teaching Fellows on the Oregon coast as a final professional development event for the project.

 

With the support of the AM&S Teaching Fellows Program, all 16 AM&S Teaching Fellows developed instructional skills in teaching ambitious goals for secondary math and science students, participated in robust opportunities to learn math and science content for teaching, and engaged in a statewide network of math and science educators spanning multiple grade levels and school districts.


Last Modified: 04/19/2022
Modified by: Thomas P Dick
